displayed_text: Patient: Right. Doctor: And, uh- (Sound Door opens) Patient: Right. Doctor: And within the apricot seeds, there’s a compound that can be converted. The downfall of the idea, so, scientifically, was actually kind of an interesting idea. But the downfall is humans don’t have the enzyme to convert the thing to cyanide. So it was never going to work because we just don’t have the enzyme. So it, so they did a lot of things, and patients went to Mexico, and they did this. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Uh, and it didn’t really have any success. What your, you’re showing me something else. I don’t know anything about vitamin B-seventeen. I didn’t know there was a B-seventeen. Patient: Yes. I know. No, nobody knows. Doctor: And so whether that’s anything that, I, I don’t know anything about that, so I can’t really tell you- Patient: Yeah. I know you don’t know about vitamins. Doctor: But that’s what the apricot seed was. Now I don’t know if they got a bunch of apricot seed ground up later on, and going, hey, we’ve got to get rid of this. Let’s go with a different story. Doctor: Uh, that would be one of my worries with all this kind of stuff. Patient: Yeah. Right. Doctor: So whenever I hear we’re going to go down to Mexico-

Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: I mean, again, if he takes them, he may eat less, but – um. Family Member: Are they just loaded with caffeine or something or? Doctor: Some of them are. Family Member: Oh. Okay. Doctor: So, when we saw you or you had came on April seventeenth, your white count was normal. You are anemic. I don’t think it’s really the iron. It may be your cancer and your treatment. It’s twenty-nine. Normal would be forty-one. Uh, and your platelets are okay. So, the only thing that we see is the low, uh, blood count, blood cells. Um. Your liver looks good. (Pause) Patient: I was on chemo ‘til February? Maybe that’s why the blood count’s down. I don’t know. (Pause) Family Member: Is that a (Pause35sec) Doctor: And your CAT scan (Pause15sec) Patient: Right. Doctor: They don’t really saw anything in your organs, your liver, all that looks good. Patient: Ah, okay. Doctor: And your bone scan (Pause6sec)

Patient: I don’t know. Doctor: Why do you make me work so hard? Patient: I don’t know. Doctor: My brain is on overdrive. Nice to see you both. I’m like racking my brain to see how to move forward and I’m just bummed out that you’re still in pain. Is this right? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Same place? Patient: Legs, mostly the legs, a little bit in the back, but I wanted to address the fatigue. That’s really… Doctor: Yeah, you just feel wiped out? Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Is that still a reaction from radiation six months ago? Doctor: No. Family Member: No, He shouldn’t have any effects from the radiation at this point? Doctor: No, I mean the only sort of culprit is untreated prostate cancer. You know if I had to sort of go back and we go a round of a bunch of pills

Family Member: Creep up. Um hum. Doctor: We rechecked him. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And then he’s got a couple of new spots in the bone which just happens to be in your skull. Family Member: Wow. Doctor: Which is, you know, no different than it is in the leg and what not but it’s a signal to us. Family Member: Oh. Exactly. Doctor: That something’s breaking through as in the shot itself is not enough. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So then you say, well, shoot, what, what could be my other options? Family Member: Right. Doctor: And then you say words like, chemotherapy. You say words like pills and other treatments. And they’re around.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: The other option again for lymph nodes of a specific size and the size limitation is more because one of the studies we have requires the smallest size of the lymph node to be one point five centimeter or higher. And that is uh a combination of a medication called Cabozantinib with an immune therapy. So that combination I think I would strongly recommend looking at if you have enough disease that needs treatment. Obviously if there’s… Patient: Are you gonna be able to find that out today? Doctor: I’m hoping to, yes. So that’s why I said let’s try and get some preliminary information on your CAT scans because that is going to be the key decision maker. Patient: More so than a bone? Doctor: I think the bone scan the problem is your report compared it to I don’t know a scan done years ago, because in between all the bone scans you had were here, they were not up there… Patient: Right. Family Member: Oh okay. Doctor: So I think I cannot do a whole lot by the report, I do need to look at the actual scan which I will do right now. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So I’ll tell you about both those things I’m hoping today before you leave. Patient: Before we leave.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.disagree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::disagree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed
Which of the following best describe you.Student: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Student

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.Yes, Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::Yes, Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Patient: Oh, okay. Family Member: Okay? Doctor: Okay. So should I give you a script today is what I’m thinking? Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Because uh that way you don’t have to scramble last minute. Doctor: What is he on? The Norco, right? Family Member: The Norco. He has Doctor: Okay. Ten’s or? Family Member: No. He’s on five. What you need to tell her now while she’s writing, do, do they take your pain completely away? The thing that bothers me is at night, he still doesn’t sleep, and you’re still in pain. Doctor: So should I give you the higher dose, or do you thing? Patient: Yeah. Yeah. I can manage. Family Member: And if he doesn’t-

Patient: It was in September, late September. Doctor: How are you? Patient: Doin’ good! Doctor: Uh, what’s goin’ on? Jaw still troubling you? Patient: A little bit, yeah. It’s, it’s, uh, right, right in, um in here. Right here. And the teeth are a little bit sensitive, just in spots Doctor: Gotten better or gotten worse? Patient: Um, it’s gotten better. Definitely gotten better. There’s still, uh, the little lump here, like a cyst. So, saw the ear, nose, and uh, throat specialist, and I have that right here where it’s drained. So, he gave me some ointment, um, prescription ointment that I put on every day, a couple times a day. Uh, I go back to see him in January, and you know, he just said, you know, to monitor it and make sure if anything gets worse to call him immediately. Doctor: And do they think this is related to the teeth or? Patient: They think so. Yeah. Doctor: Do you know how long you’ve had that lump? Patient: Um, uh, it started in, in August, late August. I, I, can see that it shrunk. I can see… Doctor: Did they say it’s smaller?

Patient: And that’s what is kind of annoying you know that - Doctor: Yeah, that we could not have continued it. Patient: At least - Doctor: But you really had a off-the-chart benefit with that. Okay. Agreed. Patient: And if I had you know two more treatments, would it have been enough you know? Doctor: I don’t know. Patient: But where do you draw the line as to how much you can take, you know? Well - Doctor: I don’t know. Well, that’s the problem. Patient: It didn’t affect me Doctor: Safety-wise, right now it’s only six months, you know. And there are some unexpected effects that are coming out for radium with um Zytiga because people have had, well there’s no problems with just adding the radium- Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: on top of the Zytiga. Now two/three years later, the study that they did of the combination is reporting way more factures and issues. Family Member: OOH!

Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So I think that is something to track down obviously, but um we’ll have to see how it goes. I’m just hoping you know we definitely have the Lynparza sort of as a fall back. Um again- Patient: So I’d be two steps away from chemo. Doctor: But getting that as well not quite and who knows how many more steps we’ll find as we go along, you know. Like I said this BET inhibitor wasn’t there what six months ago if you had needed this option and it wasn’t there for you. So it’s changed very rapidly. Patient: Everything is brand new. Doctor: Yeah but obviously we should jump on that if we can. Patient: And will they give me the uh BET thing as part of the clinical trial? Doctor: Yeah, yeah that is part of it. Patient: So I’m in a new clinical trial basically. Doctor: Yes. Patient: And they’ll give me that as part of the clinical trial Doctor: Absolutely Patient: so no out-of-pocket for us?

Family Member: He didn’t care. Doctor: Multiple. Healthcare Professional: Excuse me. He did have labs done. Doctor: Yeah. He told me that. So the PSA is what? Healthcare Professional: Sixty. Doctor: Sixty? So here it’s sixty point four. (Sound Door closes) Patient: No. I want it. I want to get it over with. Doctor: Okay. (Laughter) Family Member: Right. Patient: The longer I wait, the more things break on me. You know what I mean? Doctor: Well. Family Member: Yeah, because we have a whole schedule of appointments. Doctor: Okay. So when are his, uh, eye surgeries scheduled?

Patient: Most of stuff I had looked up, and so it’s okay now. Now, does this drug actually kill the cancer? Doctor: Um hum. Patient: It does? Doctor: Um hum. Patient: So it’s almost like a chemotherapy? Doctor: Well, it’s like a super hormone. That’s really what it is. It sits in the hormone pathway, so, it’ll kill it like that. Family Member: Because you need the hormone to kill the cancer? Doctor: Yeah. Which is why it’s not going to be like you have hair loss and all that because it’s not a chemo, per se, but it’ll shut it down. Yep. Cool. Okay. All right. Patient: That’s about it. Doctor: Um hum. Keep the phone, not the paperwork. I’ll check my e-mail and see where we are, and if you have to go make some phone calls, C___, you’ll know what to do. Family Member: I need the pharmacy to call me or go harass somebody. Patient: Good luck with that. (Laughs)

Patient: Yeah. Right. Right. Yeah. Not too much. Doctor: Not too much. Yeah. (Laughter) Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Everything went okay and smoothly? Family Member: Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. I’m fine. Yeah. Patient: So we get the shot right here? Doctor: Yeah. Yes. So how do you like the new trailer? Slowly, then the scans, everything is going to move here. Patient: Really? Doctor: Two years. Patient: Two years? Yeah. Family Member: Are they building a bigger building? Doctor: They are. Okay. That’s fine. Going to expand quite a bit. We were kind of bursting at the seams there so they needed to do it, but it’s going to be on a much bigger scale.

Family Member: You look cute. Doctor: Thank you. You know it’s interesting how guys never notice and every one of the spouses has noticed. (Laughs) Patient: Well it’s something, a non-prescription over-the-counter thing doc. Doctor: Oh, okay. Patient: They didn’t have antivert. Family Member: They don’t seem to use it. Doctor: Oh you were in Canada. Family Member: The doctor didn’t even want to – he wouldn’t prescribe it, then he did prescribe it and we went to the pharmacy and they said we don’t carry it. Patient: But he directed us to an over-the-counter thing that worked really well. So that helped a lot. Doctor: It must have been scopolamine or something. Family Member: Yeah it was for anti-nausea. Patient: Anyway so I understand I have one point four from point four? Doctor: Yes. So the PSA is going up and the scans are showing slight worsening.

Family Member: Right. Doctor: Not that. You’re doing everything right. You are. Doctor: Everything from the music to showing up when you’re supposed to. You’re doing all the right things. Patient: Hum. Doctor: You really are. It’s just that the cancer doesn’t care. Patient: I get it. Doctor: It’s the cancer that’s doing all bad things. I care. Family Member: Right. Doctor: The cancer doesn’t care so we need to be ahead of it. Patient: I’m with you. Doctor: Because you know it was nasty when we started. Family Member: I know.

Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: And then so that could be one of the first things that drops the PSA and then we expect with that shot that you received that it’s going to drop it even further. And so that’s what we’re looking for today. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And so we’re really with our fingers crossed that you know your cancer is shrinking and diving because of what we’ve done, and uh that the issue with that big amount of cancer that is around how your urine gets out of your body—that also will improve, and then we could think about getting your catheter out. Patient: Uh hum. That sounds good. Doctor: This is a copy for us. Patient: Yes. Family Member: Right. I have the originals - Family Member: Okay we have good questions. We talked about it – Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: - before and you told us to stay away from the Doctor: Yeah.
